close_symbols: Any standard <string.h> functions used by OS_TranslatePath or OS_DirCreate_Impl (e.g. strncpy, strcpy, strlen, strnlen, strncat, strcat, memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strspn)
explanation:
OS_TranslatePath: The target function passes local_path to OS_TranslatePath which is the likely site of any string copies or concatenations that could overflow local_path. You must inspect its implementation to see which string functions are used and whether bounds checks against the destination buffer are performed.

OS_DirCreate_Impl: After OS_TranslatePath returns, OS_mkdir passes local_path to OS_DirCreate_Impl. That callee may also use string handling functions on the buffer (reading or further copying) and could cause or assume certain layout/termination of local_path; its implementation is needed to determine any subsequent out-of-bounds accesses.

OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN: This macro/constant defines the size of local_path in OS_mkdir. To determine whether any string operations in OS_TranslatePath or OS_DirCreate_Impl exceed the destination buffer, the exact numeric value (and any related sizing rules) is required.

OS_strnlen: OS_TranslatePath is known (from the call graph) to call OS_strnlen; the precise semantics/implementation of this wrapper (e.g. whether it behaves like POSIX strnlen) affect length calculations and any truncation/limits used when copying into local_path.

Any standard <string.h> functions used by OS_TranslatePath or OS_DirCreate_Impl: To check compliance with the MISRA rule you must review the actual uses of standard string functions (strcpy/strncpy/strcat/strncat/strlen/memcpy/memmove/etc.) in those implementations to verify they cannot access beyond object bounds. Include the implementations/prototypes of whichever of these functions are invoked so their usage sites can be audited for proper bounds checks and correct length arguments.
